title: STAT 109: Introductory Biostatistics
text:
Quick Start

Course Schedule - Weekly schedule and course materials
Course Syllabus - Detailed course information and policies
Lectures - All course lectures organized by week
Assessments - Quizzes, exams, and projects
Resources - Textbook, R downloads, and reference materials

title: STAT 109: Introductory Biostatistics
text:
Course Overview
STAT 109: Introductory Biostatistics (4 units) introduces descriptive statistics, probability, random variables, distributions, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, regression, and ANOVA with emphasis on applications in biological and natural resource sciences.
Lecture: Monday, Wednesday, Friday, 11:00–11:50 AM, BSS 166
Lab: Thursday (select one section: 9:00–10:50 AM, 11:00–12:50 PM, or 1:00–2:50 PM), FH 202
General Education: Lower Division GE Area 2 (Quantitative Reasoning)

title: STAT 109: Introductory Biostatistics
text:
Course Structure
Includes collaborative daily warm-ups, weekly programming labs, weekly quizzes, two midterms, and five portfolio ready projects. Optional final exam may replace one midterm grade.

title: STAT 109: Introductory Biostatistics
text:
Instructor Information
Instructor: Dr. Rosanna Overholser
Office: BSS 334
Email: rho3@humboldt.edu
Office Hours: Mondays 2-3pm, Wednesdays 12-12:50pm, Fridays 10-10:50am, or by appointment

title: Quiz 2
text:
Topics:
- Basic R syntax (from Lab 1)
- Counts, proportions, and percentages (from Lecture 2)
- Probability language and definitions (from Lecture 2)




This quiz will be graded on correctness during the first twenty minutes of our Thursday lab.
You may not use notes, the internet, or a peer.
For R questions, write by hand valid R code exactly as you would type it in R.





Write valid R code for each question by hand.



Write a single line of R code that produces the value 10 by adding two numbers.




Write a single line of R code that produces the value 6 by multiplying two numbers.




Write R code that: 1. assigns the value 16 to a variable named x, and
2. computes the square root of x.




Write R code that creates a vector named numbers containing the values:
2, 4, 6, 8, 10




Using the vector numbers from Question 4, write R code that returns the third element of the vector.




Using the vector numbers, write R code that creates a new vector called numbers_plus_one that adds 1 to every element of numbers.




Write R code that computes the mean of the vector numbers.




Suppose the vector below stores the results of 6 coin flips:
flips <- c("H", "T", "H", "H", "T", "H")
Write R code that counts how many times "H" appears in the vector by using ‘==’ and a second vector, heads <- c("H", "H", "H", "H", "H", "H"). Hint: use the sum() function and the fact that TRUE is equivalent to 1 and FALSE is equivalent to 0.





A student flips a fair coin 20 times and records the results.
They observe 9 heads.



What is the value of: - \(x\), the number of times the event “head” occurred?
- \(n\), the total number of trials?




Compute the observed proportion of heads, \(\hat{p}\).
Show your calculation.




Convert the observed proportion of heads into a percentage.








Using correct notation, clearly state: - the observed proportion of heads using \(\hat{p}\) - the theoretical probability of heads for a fair coin using \(P(\text{head})\)




In one or two sentences, explain the difference between:

\(\hat{p}\)

\(P(\text{event})\)

Your answer should refer to data and long-run behavior.








State the definition of probability that involves: - a repeatable random process
- a proportion
- the idea that the process continues forever
You may write this in words.




Give a clear definition of each term:

Sample space

Outcome

Event





Consider rolling a single six-sided die.

What is the sample space?

Give one outcome.

Give one event.
